title.narrative: Tanzania Country Programme. Good Governance and Human Rights

description.narrative: The Governance and Rights Programme 2016-21 will contribute to the promotion of democracy, good governance, rule of law and respect for human rights with a special focus on women. The theory of change for the programme is based on the assumption that democratic, transparent and accountable governance where women’s rights are equal to men’s provides the most fertile ground for economic development and eradication of poverty and inequality. Strengthening of demand-side governance will contribute to stronger institutional checks and balances, empower citizens, and enhance the potential impact of Danish support provided to Government. In the short-term, change is expected in terms of a stronger and more vocal civil society, increasingly demanding transparency and responsive governance from duty bearers, as well as an increased access to justice for women and men. A particular change is expected in terms of increased awareness of and respect for women’s rights.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative: Animators and people’s representatives (in select areas) mobilise citizen accountability actions and participation in problem-solving.

Citizens have the ability, willingness and opportunity to articulate their problems, come together to discuss them, express their views in the public sphere and take civic actions to address these challenges. They are acting, organising for change, and they use multiple strategies to do so.

target.value: Animation program established: at least 20 animators recruited and trained, participatory baseline, participatory monitoring and annual assessment of the animation process conducted in at least three districts.

actual.value: 22 animators were recruited and trained to identify, train, mentor, equip and inspire local change agents to address locally defined problems in Mbogwe and Kigoma-Ujiji.

target.value: One new district for animation; at least 10 new animators recruited and trained, participatory baseline participatory monitoring and annual assessment of the animation process conducted in new district.

actual.value: In 2020, our animation activities in new districts of Pangani and Nyang’hwale were still at early stages. Fieldwork activities were slowed down by Covid-19, but we managed to conduct preliminary activities such as scoping studies and introductory visits to these two districts.

target.value: One new district for animation; at least 10 new animators recruited and trained, participatory baseline participatory monitoring and annual assessment of the animation process conducted in new district.

actual.value: Maswa: New animation District. The work in Maswa is at preliminary stages. We identified and contracted a local NGO, KASODEFO that we are partnering with in implementing the animation work there. Subsequently we worked with KASODEFO and Tamasha in identifying and training change agents from 18 villages who conducted participatory research sessions in their villages, established people’s independent monitoring committees and who together with the members of the communities produced draft action plans by the close of the year.

target.value: Lessons synthesized and shared, animator gathering.

title.narrative: CSOs and individual activists have increased operational (advocacy, financial management and fundraising) and programmatic (tools, skills, resources, networks) capacities, ultimately resulting in greater trust from citizens.
Evidence of new, different initiatives and improved organizational capacity for targeted CSOs

target.value: Initiating or participating in at least two joint civil society actions; maintaining active membership of at least one coalition; at least three capacity exchanges with CSOs

actual.value: During 2019, Twaweza coordinated of several joint analysis, engagement and advocacy such as around the Political Parties Bill, Registration Laws, BASATA Law, and the Teleza Campaign. Moreover, they conducted learning exchange visits with like-minded organizations in Uganda: Raising Voices and Chapter 4

target.value: Initiating or participating in at least two joint civil society actions; maintaining active membership of at least one coalition; at least three capacity exchanges with CSOs

actual.value:
In Tanzania, we worked to develop a new model of partnership to support organisations whose work we view as inherently valuable to our broader vision. This includes capacity development and exchange support, establishment of systems and procedures, advisory services. We initiated such partnerships with JamiiForums, The Chanzo and Equality for Growth.
We supported the development of a new strategy for Tanzania Centre for Democracy (a forum for all political parties) and for Tanzania Editors' Forum.

target.value: Initiating or participating in at least two joint civil society actions; maintaining active membership of at least one coalition; at least three capacity exchanges with CSOs

actual.value: a) Partnership agreement with the editors' forum to shift editors' mind-sets on their role in society, governance and development. b) Partnership with Equality for Growth - supported them on monitoring and evaluation design, content production to encourage voting and a shared priority agenda. Lead to a program of capacity support in 2021. c) Through Twaweza support and encouragement, two young gender activists have registered a new organisation to work on gender issues through media production. d) Twaweza supported Tanzania Bora Initiative to finalise the youth manifesto event and help them to design a five year program. e) Twaweza collaborated with PACOPA in conducting water quality assessment in 40 sub-villages of Pangani, Tanga region. f) Twaweza supported Tree of Hope organization of Tanga to conduct women’s day commemorational activities in Pangani

title.narrative: Production of a set of annual and bi-annual survey and research findings describing trends in Tanzania's media and civic space.
Civic space mapping; Citizen ATI check; LG responsiveness assessment; Gvt websites accessibility; use of Open data by LGA’s and local CSO’s.

target.value: Citizen ATI check carried out; Civic space mapping report published.

actual.value: Citizen ATI check carried out; Civic space mapping report published.

target.value: Civic space mapping report repeated; Use of Open Data by LGA’s and CSO’s carried out and published. Citizen ATI check published.

actual.value: Civic space findings were presented in the Demokrasia Yetu publication. Demokrasia Yetu was a public event by Twaweza that featured an open dialogue on democracy and civic space. Civic space mapping was postponed to 2018. One rapid response round on ATI was completed in SzW; questionnaires and database available online for public use.

target.value: Civic space mapping report repeated; Citizen ATI check repeated and published; Use of Open Data by LGA’s and CSO’s repeated and published.

actual.value: Launched a Sauti za Wananchi, Scale up of Mbunge live show.

target.value: LG responsiveness assessment carried out and published.

title.narrative: Independent monitoring and public opinion inform public debate and policy making.
Views on key public issues are gathered in a rigorous manner, printed in easy-to-read factual briefs and publicly launched in monthly cycles. (Sauti za Wananchi).

target.value: SzW: 10 rounds completed. including public launches with debates. printed briefs. posting on Twaweza website including raw data. Uwezo: Assessment completed in 56 districts (statistically representative at district and national level). now including an elaborate pilot assessing selected SDG related indicators (a.o. nutrition. drinking water. sanitation. health. institutions. disability).

actual.value:
10 call rounds done and 1 rapid response round on ATI; questionnaires and database available online for public use. Panel response rate healthy at 90+%. 7 research briefs and press releases shared actively with distribution list. launched at National Museum. 2 office based press conferences and data packets. 2 articles.
Uwezo: The Uwezo annual learning assessment was carried out in a nationally and regionally representative sample of 56 districts. A total of 6 SDGs were selected (SDG1. SDG2. SDG3. SDG4. SDG6. SDG16) and questions developed based on selected indicators. pretested. piloted and incorporated. The questions addressed issues around access to water and treatment for quality. under five child clinic care. antenatal care seeking behavior. family socioeconomic status. access to sanitation facilities. nutrition. disability and inclusiveness. and birth certificates. Data entry and reporting will be done in 2018. Briefs to be produced after report writing is completed.

target.value: SzW: 10 rounds completed. including public launches with debates. printed briefs. posting on our website including raw data. Handbook Mobile Phone Surveys published together with the Worldbank. Uwezo: East African report launched. Uwezo Tz 2015 report launched.

SzW: 10 rounds completed. including public launches with debates. printed briefs. posting on our website including raw data. Uwezo: Uwezo Tz 2017 report launched. Assessment completed in 60+ districts. including assessing selected SDG related indicators.

actual.value: 11 call rounds done (7 national sample; 4 Dar es Salaam); questionnaires for 4 national sample rounds and related database available online for public use.

target.value: SzW: 10 rounds completed. including public launches with debates. printed briefs. posting on our website including raw data. The entire panel of 2200 respondents replaced to avoid bias. Uwezo: Uwezo Tz 2018 launched. Assessment completed in all remaining districts (60+). including assessing selected SDG related indicators.

actual.value: 8 call rounds done, but government suspended Twaweza to conduct SzW in September.

target.value: SzW: 10 rounds of mobile surveys per annum completed and publicly launched. The entire panel of 2200 respondents replaced to avoid bias. Uwezo: Uwezo learning assessment conducted in all 159 districts. to be repeated every other year.

title.narrative: Citizens' views and data on key public issues are shared widely and inform public (media) and policy (parliament) debate. (O3)
- Sauti za Wananchi (SzW) is a rigorous mechanism in Tanzania that amplifies voice, opinions and perspectives of citizens to their leaders and to the wider public.

target.value: Citizens have the ability, willingness and opportunity to articulate their problems, come together to discuss them, express their views in the public sphere and take civic actions to address these challenges. They are acting, organising for change, and they use multiple strategies to do so.
